Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Bone tumour arising from metaphysis? Options: A) Osteogenic sarcoma B) Ewing sarcoma C) Osteoclastoma D) Osteiod osteoma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. is 'a' i.e., Osteogenic sarcomaMetaphvseal lesions Diaphyseal lesions o Osteogenic sarcoma o Ewing sarcomao Unicameral (simple) bone cyst o Lymphomaso Aneurysmal bone cyst o Fibrous dysplasiao Fibrous coical defect o AdamantinomaHistiocytosisOsteoid osteoma Therefore, the correct answer is A) Osteogenic sarcoma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Role of macrophages in antibody production is? Options: A) Antigen presentation B) B cell production C) Class switching D) B cell activation<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Antigen presentation.

Macrophages play a crucial role in the immune response by presenting antigens to T-cells, which helps to activate the T-cells and trigger an immune response. This process is known as antigen presentation. Macrophages engulf and process antigens, breaking them down into smaller peptides that are then displayed on their surface in association with major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules. This allows T-cells to recognize the antigens and become activated, leading to the production of antibodies and other immune responses.

The other options are not correct:

* B) B cell production: Macrophages do not produce B cells.
* C) Class switching: Macrophages do not play a direct role in class switching, which is the process by which B cells switch from producing one type of antibody to another.
* D) B cell activation: While macrophages can activate B cells by presenting antigens to them, they do not directly activate B cells. Instead, the activation of B cells typically occurs through the interaction of antigens with B cell receptors.<|eot_id|>

Question: Hereditary retinoblastoma develop as a result of which of the following chromosomal deletion? Options: A) 13q 14 B) 13p 14 C) 14p 13 D) 14q 13<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) 13q14.

Hereditary retinoblastoma is a rare genetic disorder that is caused by a mutation in the RB1 gene, which is located on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q14). This mutation leads to the development of retinoblastoma, a type of eye cancer that typically affects children.

The RB1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene, and its mutation leads to the loss of its normal function, allowing uncontrolled cell growth and division to occur. This can result in the development of retinoblastoma, which can be bilateral (affecting both eyes) or unilateral (affecting one eye).

The other options are not correct because:

* 13p14 is not a known location for the RB1 gene.
* 14p13 is not a known location for the RB1 gene.
* 14q13 is not a known location for the RB1 gene.

Therefore, the correct answer is A) 13q14.<|eot_id|>

Question: A 11-year-old boy came with history of cough for 15 days. On examination he was found to have cervical lymphadenopathy. The lymph node biopsy is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis? Options: A) Tuberculosis B) Leprosy C) Sarcoidosis D) Syphilis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The image shows a granuloma with a characteristic "caseating" necrosis, which is a hallmark of Tuberculosis (TB). The presence of caseating granulomas in the lymph node biopsy suggests a diagnosis of Tuberculosis.

The other options are not consistent with the findings:

* Leprosy typically causes granulomas with foamy macrophages and is not typically associated with caseating necrosis.
* Sarcoidosis can cause granulomas, but they are typically non-caseating and do not have the same characteristic features as those seen in TB.
* Syphilis can cause granulomas, but they are typically associated with a more diffuse and non-caseating pattern of inflammation.

Therefore, the most appropriate diagnosis is A) Tuberculosis.<|eot_id|>

Question: Source of vitamin B12? Options: A) Animal source B) Plant source C) Milk D) Fruits<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Animal source.

Vitamin B12 is a water-soluble vitamin that is found primarily in animal products, such as:

* Meat (beef, pork, lamb)
* Poultry (chicken, turkey)
* Fish (salmon, tuna)
* Eggs
* Dairy products (milk, cheese, yogurt)
* Fortified plant-based milk and cereals

Vitamin B12 is not found in plant-based foods, such as fruits, vegetables, and grains. Therefore, option D) Fruits is incorrect.

Option B) Plant source is also incorrect because while some plant-based foods may be fortified with vitamin B12, they are not a natural source of the vitamin.

Option C) Milk is a good source of vitamin B12, but it is not the only source, and option A) Animal source is the most comprehensive answer.<|eot_id|>

Question: Histologic sections of skin from an area of sunburn would most likely reveal: Options: A) Epidermal edema B) Intraepidermal vesicles C) Full-thickness epithelial necrosis D) Partial dermal necrosis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Epidermal edema.

Sunburn is a type of acute radiation injury caused by excessive exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun or other sources. Histologically, sunburn is characterized by:

* Epidermal edema: The epidermis becomes swollen and edematous due to increased permeability of blood vessels.
* Epidermal cell damage: Sun-exposed keratinocytes undergo apoptosis (programmed cell death) and become detached from the basement membrane, leading to a loss of epidermal integrity.
* Dermal inflammation: A mild inflammatory response occurs in the dermis, characterized by the presence of lymphocytes, macrophages, and neutrophils.

Intraepidermal vesicles (option B) are not typically seen in sunburn. Full-thickness epithelial necrosis (option C) is not a characteristic feature of sunburn, although it can occur in severe cases. Partial dermal necrosis (option D) is also not a typical finding in sunburn.<|eot_id|>

Question: Salivary gland tumor exclusively seen in parotid gland Options: A) Wahin's tumor B) Pleomorphic adenoma C) Mucoepidermoid Ca D) Adenoid cystic Ca<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Wahin's tumor.

Wahin's tumor is a type of salivary gland tumor that is exclusively seen in the parotid gland. It is a benign tumor that typically affects adults and is characterized by a slow-growing, painless swelling in the parotid gland.

The other options are not exclusively seen in the parotid gland:

* Pleomorphic adenoma is a common type of salivary gland tumor that can occur in any of the major salivary glands, including the parotid gland, submandibular gland, and sublingual gland.
* Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is a type of malignant tumor that can occur in any of the major salivary glands, including the parotid gland, submandibular gland, and sublingual gland.
* Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a type of malignant tumor that can occur in any of the major salivary glands, including the parotid gland, submandibular gland, and sublingual gland.<|eot_id|>

Question: Echinocytes are types of - Options: A) RBC's B) Lymphocytes C) Monocytes D) Platelets<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) RBC's (Red Blood Cells).

Echinocytes are a type of abnormal red blood cell that has a characteristic echinocytic shape, characterized by the presence of numerous small, rounded projections or "echini" on the surface of the cell. This is often seen in conditions such as hereditary spherocytosis, hereditary elliptocytosis, and some cases of hemolytic anemia.

Lymphocytes (Option B) are a type of white blood cell, not red blood cell.

Monocytes (Option C) are a type of white blood cell, not red blood cell.

Platelets (Option D) are a type of blood cell involved in blood clotting, not red blood cells.<|eot_id|>

Question: Lipoxins synthesized from arachidonic acid act by- Options: A) Decrease leucocyte migration, adhesion, chemotaxis B) Increase leucocyte migration, adhesion, chemotaxis C) Vasoconstriction D) Increased vascular permeability<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Decrease leucocyte migration, adhesion, chemotaxis.

Lipoxins are a family of eicosanoids that are synthesized from arachidonic acid through the action of 15-lipoxygenase. They are produced by activated neutrophils and play a key role in the resolution of inflammation.

Lipoxins have several anti-inflammatory effects, including:

* Inhibiting the migration, adhesion, and chemotaxis of neutrophils and other leukocytes
* Reducing the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines
* Inhibiting the activation of platelets and the release of platelet-derived growth factor
* Reducing the production of reactive oxygen species and nitric oxide

Overall, lipoxins help to promote the resolution of inflammation and tissue repair by reducing the inflammatory response and promoting the clearance of inflammatory cells and debris.<|eot_id|>

Question: Factors affecting sickling in sickle cell anemia are - Options: A) HbS concentration B) HbA C) pH D) Oxygenation<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) HbS concentration, B) pH, and D) Oxygenation.

Sickling of red blood cells in sickle cell anemia is influenced by the following factors:

* HbS concentration: The higher the concentration of HbS, the more likely the red blood cells are to sickle.
* pH: Acidic conditions (low pH) increase the likelihood of sickling, while alkaline conditions (high pH) decrease it.
* Oxygenation: Deoxygenation of red blood cells increases the likelihood of sickling, while oxygenation decreases it.

HbA (normal hemoglobin) does not directly affect sickling, so option B is incorrect.

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a point mutation in the HBB gene that codes for the beta-globin protein, leading to the production of HbS instead of HbA. The HbS molecule has a different structure that causes it to polymerize and form fibers when deoxygenated, leading to the characteristic sickling of red blood cells.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Apoptoic bodies are? Options: A) Pyknotic nucleus with organelles B) Opened up chromatin bodies C) Membrane bound cytoplasm without organelles D) Clumped chromatin bodies<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Pyknotic nucleus with organelles.

Apoptotic bodies are small, membrane-bound vesicles that contain cellular components, including organelles, that are released from the cell during the process of apoptosis (programmed cell death). They typically contain a pyknotic nucleus, which is a nucleus that has undergone condensation and fragmentation, as well as organelles such as mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, and ribosomes.

Pyknosis is a characteristic feature of apoptosis, where the nucleus becomes condensed and fragmented, leading to the formation of a pyknotic nucleus.

The other options are not correct:

* B) Opened up chromatin bodies: This is not a characteristic feature of apoptotic bodies.
* C) Membrane-bound cytoplasm without organelles: Apoptotic bodies typically contain organelles, not just cytoplasm.
* D) Clumped chromatin bodies: While chromatin condensation is a feature of apoptosis, it is not typically clumped or aggregated in apoptotic bodies.<|eot_id|>

Question: Tuberous sclerosis is inherited as? Options: A) Autosomal dominant B) Autosomal recessive C) X-linked dominant D) X-linked recessive<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Autosomal dominant.

Tuberous sclerosis is a rare genetic disorder that is caused by mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 genes, which are located on chromosomes 9q34 and 16p13, respectively. The disorder is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning that a single copy of the mutated gene is enough to cause the condition. This means that if one parent has the condition, each child has a 50% chance of inheriting the mutated gene and developing the condition.

It's worth noting that the condition can also occur sporadically, meaning that it can occur in individuals who do not have a family history of the condition. This is due to new mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 genes.<|eot_id|>

Question: Alpha fetoprotein is not raised in which testicular tumor Options: A) Choriocarcinoma B) Tearatacarcinoma C) Yolk sac tumor D) Embryonal cell carcinoma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) Embryonal cell carcinoma.

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a tumor marker that is typically elevated in germ cell tumors of the testis, including:

* Yolk sac tumor (endodermal sinus tumor)
* Choriocarcinoma
* Teratocarcinoma

However, embryonal cell carcinoma is a type of germ cell tumor that does not typically produce AFP. Instead, it produces human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).

So, the correct answer is D) Embryonal cell carcinoma.<|eot_id|>

Question: Dyskeratosis means Options: A) Abnormal,premature keratinization within cells  below  the stratum granulosum B) Discontinuity  of the  skin showing incomplete loss of epidermis C) Thickening   of stratum corneum, often associated with a  qualitative  abnormality of keratin D) Keratinization with retained nuclei in the stratum corneum<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Abnormal, premature keratinization within cells below the stratum granulosum.

Dyskeratosis is a term used to describe the abnormal, premature keratinization of cells in the stratum spinosum or stratum granulosum, resulting in the formation of keratin-filled cells that are not yet fully differentiated. This can occur in various skin conditions, including psoriasis, ichthyosis, and keratosis follicularis.

The other options are not accurate definitions of dyskeratosis:

B) Discontinuity of the skin showing incomplete loss of epidermis is a description of a skin defect, not a specific histopathological feature.

C) Thickening of the stratum corneum, often associated with a qualitative abnormality of keratin, is a description of a condition called ichthyosis, not dyskeratosis.

D) Keratinization with retained nuclei in the stratum corneum is a description of a condition called parakeratosis, not dyskeratosis.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Most commonly associated human papilloma virus with Cancer Cervix is? Options: A) HPV 16 B) HPV 24 C) HPV 32 D) HPV 36<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) HPV 16.

Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a necessary cause of cervical cancer, and HPV 16 is the most common type of HPV associated with cervical cancer. In fact, it is estimated that HPV 16 is responsible for approximately 50-60% of all cases of cervical cancer worldwide.

HPV 16 is a high-risk HPV type that can cause abnormal cell growth and progression to cancer. It is typically transmitted through sexual contact and can infect the cervix, leading to cervical dysplasia, carcinoma in situ, and invasive cervical cancer.

The other options are not correct:

* HPV 24 is a low-risk HPV type that is not typically associated with cervical cancer.
* HPV 32 is not a well-established type of HPV associated with cervical cancer.
* HPV 36 is a high-risk HPV type, but it is not as commonly associated with cervical cancer as HPV 16.

It's worth noting that HPV 18 is also a high-risk HPV type that is associated with cervical cancer, but it is less common than HPV 16.<|eot_id|>

Question: The risk of sarcoma developing in a fibroid uterus is approximately Options: A) <1% B) <10% C) >30% D) >50%<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) <1%.

Sarcoma uteri, also known as uterine sarcoma, is a rare type of cancer that arises from the muscle or connective tissue of the uterus. The risk of developing uterine sarcoma in a woman with a uterine fibroid is extremely low, estimated to be less than 1% (0.1-0.5%). This is because fibroids are benign tumors that are not typically associated with an increased risk of cancer. However, some rare types of fibroids, such as leiomyosarcomas, can undergo malignant transformation and become sarcomas.<|eot_id|>

Question: Which of the following causes 'no-reflow' phenomenon in acute myocardial infarction contributing to reperfusion injury? Options: A) Myocyte hypercontracture: B) Leucocyte aggregation C) Free radicals D) Complement activation<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Leucocyte aggregation.

The "no-reflow" phenomenon is a common complication of reperfusion therapy in acute myocardial infarction, characterized by the failure of previously ischemic myocardium to reperfuse despite successful recanalization of the occluded coronary artery. Leucocyte aggregation is a major contributor to the "no-reflow" phenomenon. Leucocytes, particularly neutrophils, can adhere to the endothelium and each other, forming aggregates that occlude the microvasculature and prevent blood flow to the ischemic myocardium.

Myocyte hypercontracture (Option A) is a phenomenon that occurs in response to ischemia, but it is not directly related to the "no-reflow" phenomenon.

Free radicals (Option C) can contribute to reperfusion injury, but they are not the primary cause of the "no-reflow" phenomenon.

Complement activation (Option D) can also contribute to reperfusion injury, but it is not a direct cause of the "no-reflow" phenomenon.

Therefore, the correct answer is B) Leucocyte aggregation.<|eot_id|>

Question: Which type of anemia is seen in patients of rheumatoid ahritis? Options: A) Normocytic and hypochromic anemia B) Normocytic and normochromic anemia C) Macrocytic anemia D) Sideroblastic anemia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Normocytic and normochromic anemia.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is often associated with anemia, which is typically normocytic and normochromic. This type of anemia is caused by a combination of factors, including:

1. Chronic inflammation: Inflammation in the joints and surrounding tissues can lead to the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, which can suppress erythropoiesis and lead to anemia.
2. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency is common in RA patients due to chronic inflammation, which can lead to increased iron loss in the stool and decreased iron absorption.
3. Vitamin B12 deficiency: RA patients are at risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency due to malabsorption or gastrointestinal inflammation, which can contribute to anemia.
4. Chronic disease: RA is a chronic condition, and chronic disease can lead to anemia due to decreased erythropoietin production and increased red blood cell destruction.

Normocytic and normochromic anemia is characterized by a normal mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC), but a decreased red blood cell count. This type of anemia is often seen in patients with chronic inflammatory diseases, such as RA.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Bone tumour arising from metaphysis? Options: A) Osteogenic sarcoma B) Ewing sarcoma C) Osteoclastoma D) Osteiod osteoma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Question: Calcitonin is a marker of - Options: A) Prostate cancer B) Medullary carcinoma of thyroid C) Pheochromocytoma D) Pancreatic cancer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Medullary carcinoma of thyroid.

Calcitonin is a hormone produced by the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland. It is often used as a tumor marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma, a type of thyroid cancer that arises from these C cells. Elevated levels of calcitonin in the blood can indicate the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma.

While calcitonin is not typically associated with the other options:

* Prostate cancer: PSA (prostate-specific antigen) is the primary tumor marker for prostate cancer.
* Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that produces catecholamines, such as epinephrine and norepinephrine. The primary tumor marker for pheochromocytoma is usually vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) or metanephrines.
* Pancreatic cancer: CA 19-9 is a common tumor marker for pancreatic cancer.

Therefore, the correct answer is B) Medullary carcinoma of thyroid.<|eot_id|>

Question: Caplan's syndrome is seen in: Options: A) COPD B) Pneumoconiosis C) Pulmonary edema D) Bronchial asthma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Pneumoconiosis.

Caplan's syndrome is a rare complication of pneumoconiosis, particularly in coal miners. It is characterized by the development of a rheumatoid arthritis-like syndrome, often accompanied by a skin rash, in individuals with pneumoconiosis. The syndrome is thought to be caused by the presence of silica particles in the lungs, which can trigger an autoimmune response.

COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease) is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that is often caused by long-term exposure to lung irritants, such as cigarette smoke, air pollution, and occupational dusts. While COPD can be associated with various systemic symptoms, including joint pain and fatigue, it is not typically characterized by a specific syndrome like Caplan's syndrome.

Pulmonary edema is a condition in which fluid accumulates in the lungs, often due to heart failure, pneumonia, or other conditions. It is not typically associated with Caplan's syndrome.

Bronchial asthma is a chronic respiratory disease characterized by recurring episodes of wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath. While asthma can be associated with joint pain and other systemic symptoms, it is not typically characterized by a specific syndrome like Caplan's syndrome.<|eot_id|>

Question: Metastasis in neuroblastoma goes to - Options: A) Liver B) Lung C) Bone D) Bone marrow<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Bone.

Neuroblastoma is a type of cancer that originates in the nerve tissue of the adrenal gland or spine. It is a common childhood cancer that typically affects children under the age of 5.

Metastasis in neuroblastoma typically occurs to the following sites:

* Bone: This is the most common site of metastasis, with the skull, spine, and ribs being the most commonly affected areas.
* Bone marrow: Neuroblastoma cells can also metastasize to the bone marrow, leading to anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia.
* Liver: Neuroblastoma can also metastasize to the liver, leading to liver dysfunction and jaundice.
* Lung: Less commonly, neuroblastoma can metastasize to the lung, leading to respiratory symptoms.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) Bone.<|eot_id|>

Question: Mutations in merlin protein is associated with: Options: A) Astrocytoma B) Meningioma C) Medulloblastoma D) Oligodendroglioma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Meningioma.

Merlin (also known as NF2) is a tumor suppressor gene that is responsible for the development of meningiomas, a type of brain tumor. Mutations in the Merlin gene can lead to the development of meningiomas, which are typically benign tumors that arise from the meninges, the protective membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord.

Astrocytoma, medulloblastoma, and oligodendroglioma are all types of brain tumors, but they are not typically associated with mutations in the Merlin gene.

Merlin is a tumor suppressor gene that is involved in the regulation of cell growth and differentiation, and mutations in this gene can lead to the development of meningiomas.<|eot_id|>

Question: Schizophrenia occurring in persons with IQ less than 70 is Options: A) Simple B) Proff C) Catatonia D) Hebephrenic<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Proff.

Proff's syndrome is a rare subtype of schizophrenia that is characterized by a low IQ (typically below 70) and a severe impairment in cognitive and adaptive functioning. It is often associated with a poor prognosis and a high risk of institutionalization.

Simple schizophrenia is a term that was previously used to describe a subtype of schizophrenia characterized by a lack of prominent psychotic symptoms, but it is no longer considered a valid diagnostic category.

Catatonia is a syndrome characterized by a state of immobility, mutism, and rigidity, often accompanied by other symptoms such as agitation, aggression, and autonomic instability. While it can occur in individuals with schizophrenia, it is not a subtype of schizophrenia.

Hebephrenic schizophrenia is a term that was previously used to describe a subtype of schizophrenia characterized by a disorganized and bizarre behavior, but it is no longer considered a valid diagnostic category.

Therefore, the correct answer is B) Proff.<|eot_id|>

Question: Congenital hepatic fibrosis is predominantly associated with which cystic disease of kidney? Options: A) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) B) Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) C) Medullary sponge kidney D) Nephronophthisis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD).

Congenital hepatic fibrosis is a rare disorder characterized by the development of fibrosis in the liver, often in association with cystic kidney disease. The most common association is with Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD), which is a genetic disorder that affects the development and function of the kidneys and liver. ARPKD is characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys and liver, and can lead to kidney failure and liver fibrosis.

Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is a different condition that is characterized by the development of multiple cysts in the kidneys, but is not typically associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis.

Medullary Sponge Kidney is a rare congenital disorder characterized by the formation of multiple small cysts in the medulla of the kidneys, but is not typically associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis.

Nephronophthisis is a group of genetic disorders that are characterized by the progressive loss of kidney function and the development of cysts in the kidneys, but is not typically associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis.<|eot_id|>

Question: Pyogenic infection and brain infarction are associated with Options: A) Coagulative necrosis B) Liquefaction necrosis C) Caseous necrosis D) Fat necrosis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Liquefaction necrosis.

Pyogenic infections, such as bacterial meningitis or brain abscesses, can cause liquefaction necrosis in the brain tissue. Liquefaction necrosis is a type of coagulative necrosis that occurs when the tissue becomes liquefied due to the breakdown of cellular and extracellular components.

Coagulative necrosis (Option A) is a type of necrosis that occurs when the tissue becomes dry and shriveled, often due to a lack of blood supply.

Caseous necrosis (Option C) is a type of necrosis that occurs in granulomas, such as those caused by tuberculosis, and is characterized by the formation of a cheesy or caseous material.

Fat necrosis (Option D) is a type of necrosis that occurs when fat cells are damaged, often due to trauma or inflammation, and is characterized by the formation of a yellowish or creamy material.

Brain infarction, on the other hand, is a type of ischemic injury that occurs when the blood supply to the brain is interrupted, leading to the death of brain tissue. It is not typically associated with pyogenic infections.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 45-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. A hysterectomy is performed and shows a benign tumor of the uterus derived from a smooth muscle cell. What is the appropriate diagnosis? Options: A) Angiomyolipoma B) Leiomyoma C) Leiomyosarcoma D) Myxoma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Leiomyoma.

A leiomyoma is a benign tumor that arises from the smooth muscle cells of the uterus. It is the most common type of uterine tumor and is typically seen in women of reproductive age. Leiomyomas are usually asymptomatic, but can cause symptoms such as abnormal bleeding, pelvic pressure, and pain.

Angiomyolipoma is a benign tumor that arises from the smooth muscle cells and blood vessels of the uterus, but it is less common than leiomyoma.

Leiomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor that arises from the smooth muscle cells of the uterus and is a type of uterine sarcoma.

Myxoma is a benign tumor that arises from the connective tissue of the uterus, but it is not typically derived from smooth muscle cells.

Therefore, the correct answer is B) Leiomyoma.<|eot_id|>

Question: Tigered effect in myocardium is due to: Options: A) Malignant change B) Fat deposition C) Seen in rheumatic fever D) Associated with myocarditis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Fat deposition.

The "tigered effect" or "tiger tail" appearance is a histopathological finding in the myocardium, characterized by the presence of yellowish-white streaks or patches of fatty infiltration, which can be seen in various conditions, including:

* Cardiac lipomatosis: a benign condition characterized by the deposition of fat cells in the myocardium.
* Lipomatous hypertrophy of the interatrial septum: a benign condition characterized by the deposition of fat cells in the interatrial septum.
* Cardiac lipoma: a benign tumor composed of fat cells.

This appearance is not typically seen in malignant change (Option A), myocarditis (Option D), or rheumatic fever (Option C).<|eot_id|>

Question: A major source of collagen in cirrhosis - Options: A) Kupffer cells B) Ito cell (Hepatic stellate cell) C) Hepatocyte D) Canalicular cell<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Ito cell (Hepatic stellate cell).

In cirrhosis, the Ito cells (also known as hepatic stellate cells) undergo activation and transdifferentiation into myofibroblasts, which produce excessive amounts of collagen. This leads to the deposition of collagen in the liver, resulting in fibrosis and cirrhosis.

Kupffer cells are macrophages that reside in the liver and play a role in phagocytosis and immune function, but they are not a major source of collagen.

Hepatocytes are the main functional cells of the liver and are responsible for synthesizing and secreting various proteins, including albumin and clotting factors. While they can produce some collagen, they are not the primary source of collagen in cirrhosis.

Canalicular cells are the cells that line the bile canaliculi and are involved in bile formation and secretion. They do not produce collagen.

Therefore, the correct answer is B) Ito cell (Hepatic stellate cell).<|eot_id|>

Question: Russell’s body is found in: Options: A) Metastatic calcification B) Plasma cells C) RBC D) Mast cells<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Plasma cells.

Russell's bodies are also known as Russell bodies or Mott cells. They are a type of inclusion body found in the cytoplasm of plasma cells, which are a type of white blood cell. Russell's bodies are composed of immunoglobulins (antibodies) that have been aggregated and trapped within the plasma cell. They are a characteristic feature of multiple myeloma, a type of cancer that affects plasma cells.

Metastatic calcification (Option A) is a condition where calcium deposits form in tissues, often as a result of hypercalcemia (elevated calcium levels in the blood).

Red blood cells (Option C) do not typically contain Russell's bodies.

Mast cells (Option D) are a type of immune cell that plays a role in allergic reactions, but they do not typically contain Russell's bodies.<|eot_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Non seminal germ cell tumors of testis secrete - Options: A) CEA B) Acid phosphatase C) Alfa feto protein D) Cytokeratin<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).

Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis, such as embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, and choriocarcinoma, can produce alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). AFP is a glycoprotein that is normally produced by the yolk sac during fetal development. Elevated levels of AFP in the blood are often used as a tumor marker to monitor the response to treatment and detect recurrence of these tumors.

Seminoma, on the other hand, is a type of germ cell tumor that produces beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).

CEA (carcinoembryonic antigen) is not typically produced by testicular tumors.

Acid phosphatase is an enzyme that is often used as a marker for prostate cancer, not testicular cancer.

Cytokeratin is a protein that is found in the cytoskeleton of epithelial cells and is not typically used as a tumor marker for testicular cancer.<|eot_id|>

Question: Phagocytosis is the function of- Options: A) Astrocytes B) Oligodendrocytes C) Microglia D) Schawan cells<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Microglia.

Microglia are a type of glial cell that is found in the central nervous system (CNS) and are responsible for phagocytosis, which is the process of engulfing and digesting foreign particles, dead cells, and cellular debris. Microglia play a crucial role in the maintenance of CNS homeostasis and are involved in the removal of pathogens, dead neurons, and other cellular debris.

Astrocytes (Option A) are a type of glial cell that provide structural and metabolic support to neurons, but they do not have phagocytic activity.

Oligodendrocytes (Option B) are a type of glial cell that produce the myelin sheath that surrounds and insulates axons in the CNS, but they do not have phagocytic activity.

Schwann cells (Option D) are a type of glial cell that produce the myelin sheath that surrounds and insulates axons in the peripheral nervous system (PNS), but they do not have phagocytic activity.<|eot_id|>

Question: Which drug is used for topical application in respiratory papillomatosis? Options: A) Acyclovir B) Ranitidine C) Cidofovir D) Ribavirin<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Cidofovir.

Cidofovir is an antiviral medication that is used topically to treat respiratory papillomatosis, a condition characterized by the growth of papillomas (benign tumors) in the respiratory tract, typically caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). It is applied directly to the affected area using a spray or gel.

Acyclovir is an antiviral medication used to treat herpes simplex virus infections, such as cold sores and genital herpes.

Ranitidine is an antacid medication used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and other conditions.

Ribavirin is an antiviral medication used to treat hepatitis C and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infections.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) Cidofovir.<|eot_id|>

Question: A baby's blood group was determined as 0 Rh negative. Select the blood group the baby's mother or father will not have - Options: A) A, Rh Positive B) B, Rh Positive C) AB, Rh Negative D) O,Rh positive<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) O, Rh positive.

The baby's blood type is 0 Rh negative, which means they do not have the Rh antigen on their red blood cells. This is because the Rh antigen is inherited from the father.

The possible genotypes and phenotypes of the parents are:

* Mother: O or A or B or AB, Rh positive or negative
* Father: O or A or B or AB, Rh positive or negative

Since the baby is 0 Rh negative, the father must be Rh negative, as the Rh antigen is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Therefore, the mother cannot be Rh positive, as she would have passed on the Rh antigen to the baby.

So, the correct answer is D) O, Rh positive.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A patient with which of the follwing disease is predisposed to develop osteosarcoma -a)  Osteomalaciab)  Osteomyelitisc)  Paget's disease of boned)  Osteopetrosis Options: A) a B) c C) bc D) ad<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) bc

Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that typically affects children and young adults. The risk factors for developing osteosarcoma include:

* Paget's disease of bone: Paget's disease is a chronic bone disorder characterized by abnormal bone remodeling, which can increase the risk of developing osteosarcoma.
* Osteochondromas: Osteochondromas are benign bone tumors that can increase the risk of developing osteosarcoma.

Osteomalacia (option A) is a condition characterized by softening of the bones due to a deficiency of vitamin D or calcium, and it is not a risk factor for osteosarcoma.

Osteomyelitis (option B) is an infection of the bone, and it is not a risk factor for osteosarcoma.

Osteopetrosis (option D) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormal bone development and increased risk of bone fractures, but it is not a risk factor for osteosarcoma.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) bc, as both Paget's disease of bone and osteochondromas are risk factors for developing osteosarcoma.<|eot_id|>

Question: Chance of affected child to Autosomal recessive carrier parents is? Options: A) 10% B) 15% C) 25% D) 50%<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) 25%.

In autosomal recessive inheritance, the probability of an affected child is 25% when both parents are carriers (heterozygous) of the recessive allele. This is because each parent has a 50% chance of passing on the recessive allele to their offspring, and the offspring must inherit two copies of the recessive allele (one from each parent) to express the condition.

So, the probability of an affected child is:

* 50% chance of inheriting the recessive allele from one parent
* 50% chance of inheriting the recessive allele from the other parent
* 25% chance of inheriting two recessive alleles (affected)

Therefore, the correct answer is 25%.<|eot_id|>

Question: Shock lung is seen in? Options: A) Bronchiectasis B) Lung carcinoma C) ARDS D) COPD<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome).

Shock lung, also known as adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), is a life-threatening condition characterized by inflammation and damage to the lungs, leading to respiratory failure. It is often caused by severe trauma, sepsis, pneumonia, or other systemic illnesses. The lungs become stiff and leaky, leading to low oxygen levels in the blood and difficulty breathing.

Bronchiectasis (Option A) is a chronic condition characterized by permanent damage to the airways, leading to chronic coughing and wheezing.

Lung carcinoma (Option B) is a type of cancer that can cause respiratory symptoms, but it is not typically associated with shock lung.

COPD (Option D) is a chronic condition characterized by chronic bronchitis and emphysema, which can cause respiratory symptoms, but it is not typically associated with shock lung.<|eot_id|>

Question: Intake of which of these cause vascular lesions in liver - Options: A) Halothanes B) INH C) Steroids D) CPZ<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Steroids.

Steroids can cause vascular lesions in the liver, including:

* Peliosis hepatis: a rare condition characterized by the formation of blood-filled cysts in the liver, which can rupture and cause bleeding.
* Hepatic sinusoidal dilatation: a condition characterized by dilation of the hepatic sinusoids, which can lead to bleeding and liver failure.

Halothane (A) can cause hepatic necrosis, but not vascular lesions.

INH (B) can cause hepatitis, but not vascular lesions.

CPZ (D) is an antipsychotic medication that can cause liver damage, but not vascular lesions.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) Steroids.<|eot_id|>

Question: Schiller - Duval bodies are seen in- Options: A) Teratoma B) Seminoma C) Yolk sac tumour D) Chorio - carcinoma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Yolk sac tumour.

Schiller-Duval bodies are a characteristic histopathological feature of yolk sac tumors (endodermal sinus tumors) of the testis or ovary. They are small, rounded, and contain a central blood space surrounded by a layer of cuboidal or columnar cells. They are thought to represent the remnants of the yolk sac and are a diagnostic feature of yolk sac tumors.

Teratoma (Option A) is a type of germ cell tumor that contains tissue from two or more germ layers (ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm). It can contain a wide range of tissues, including hair, teeth, and bone, but does not typically contain Schiller-Duval bodies.

Seminoma (Option B) is a type of germ cell tumor that arises from the seminiferous tubules of the testis. It is typically composed of uniform, large, and polygonal cells with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio.

Choriocarcinoma (Option D) is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease that arises from the placenta. It is typically composed of highly malignant cells that resemble those of the placenta and can produce human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).

Therefore, the correct answer is C) Yolk sac tumour.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Question: Which of the following is not a major criteria for diagnosis of multiple myeloma? Options: A) Lytic bone lesions B) Plasmacytoma on tissue biopsy C) Bone marrow plasmacytosis > 30% D) `M' spike > 3g% for 1g G, > 2g% for IgA<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Plasmacytoma on tissue biopsy.

The major criteria for diagnosis of multiple myeloma are:

1. Lytic bone lesions (A)
2. Bone marrow plasmacytosis > 30% (C)
3. M-spike > 3g% for IgG, > 2g% for IgA (D)

Plasmacytoma on tissue biopsy is a minor criterion, not a major criterion. A plasmacytoma is a solitary tumor composed of plasma cells, whereas multiple myeloma is a systemic disease characterized by the proliferation of abnormal plasma cells in the bone marrow.

Note: The presence of a plasmacytoma on tissue biopsy is important for diagnosing a solitary plasmacytoma, which is a different entity from multiple myeloma.<|eot_id|>

Question: Which of the following is not a minor diagnositic criteria for multiple myeloma? Options: A) Lytic bone lesions B) Plasmacytosis greater than 20% C) Plasmacytoma on biopsy D) Monoclonal globuline spike on serum electrophoresis of> 2.5 g/dl for IgG, > 1.5 g/dl for IgA<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Plasmacytoma on biopsy.

The minor diagnostic criteria for multiple myeloma are:

* Lytic bone lesions
* Plasmacytosis greater than 20% on bone marrow examination
* Monoclonal globulin spike on serum electrophoresis of > 2.5 g/dl for IgG, > 1.5 g/dl for IgA

Plasmacytoma on biopsy is not a minor diagnostic criterion for multiple myeloma. A plasmacytoma is a solitary tumor composed of malignant plasma cells, whereas multiple myeloma is a systemic disease characterized by the proliferation of malignant plasma cells in the bone marrow.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) Plasmacytoma on biopsy.<|eot_id|>

Question: CD 34 is a tumor marker used for - Options: A) Ewings sarcoma B) Myofibrosarcoma C) Alveolar soft part sarcoma D) Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Alveolar soft part sarcoma.

CD34 is a cell surface protein that is commonly used as a marker for the diagnosis of alveolar soft part sarcoma (ASPS). It is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that typically affects young adults and is characterized by the presence of a specific chromosomal translocation, t(X;17)(p11;q25).

CD34 is not typically used as a marker for Ewing's sarcoma (Option A), myofibrosarcoma (Option B), or inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor (Option D).

Ewing's sarcoma is typically marked by the presence of CD99, while myofibrosarcoma is marked by the presence of desmin and vimentin. Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor is typically marked by the presence of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) protein.<|eot_id|>

Question: Ferruginous bodies are seen in - Options: A) Silicosis B) Bysinosis C) Asbestosis D) Baggassosis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Asbestosis.

Ferruginous bodies are also known as asbestos bodies or asbestos fibers. They are a hallmark of asbestos exposure and are typically seen in the lungs of individuals with asbestosis, a chronic lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibers. Ferruginous bodies are formed when iron-rich proteins in the lung react with asbestos fibers, creating a characteristic "tram-track" or "railroad track" appearance on histopathological examination.

Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica particles, and it is characterized by the formation of silicate granulomas.

Bysinosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling cotton dust, and it is characterized by the formation of cotton fibers in the lungs.

Baggassosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling bagasse, a byproduct of sugarcane processing, and it is characterized by the formation of bagasse fibers in the lungs.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) Asbestosis.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>
